title: How it feels to talk about feminism, sexism and representation on the LoL Boards

replies.body:
Greetings!

I will be disabling commenting as It seems like this discussion has been derailed into a topic which is not appropriate for our Boards and there are other avenues where these debates can be had.

I don't think people come to these boards to talk about social issues, or they shouldn't be.

Also, usually it's just keyboards warriors. XD

> I don't think people come to these boards to talk about social issues, or they shouldn't be.

People shouldn't talk about important issues that might also be in a game? 
Did you see the 100 angry threads about Fiora's not perfect face in the new splash? I guess that's what is important xDD

A lot of people come to escape that crap. Who cares if the characters in a video game don't represent real life... it's all fantasy. "omagur she makes me feel bad about my body" (I know I'm reducing the issues but I'll get to my point)

{{champion:133}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:89}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:10}} {{champion:113}} 

This is a list of strong female characters who I wouldn't call overly sexualized

I wouldn't call any of the characters sexualized... Unless you think breast are sexualized in which case you're the problem. I'll admit, many characters are sexualized but sex does sell. 
{{champion:201}} {{champion:104}} {{champion:81}} {{champion:64}} {{champion:80}} {{champion:44}} {{champion:4}}  {{champion:126}}
{{champion:103}} {{champion:84}} {{champion:21}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:254}} 

My list is from overly sexualized characters. The males fit the standards of what women find attractive in a male, and the women do it visa versa. (since you mentioned in game issues I'm using this one since it is the most common argument at any given time) 

This game isn't realistic, you have tentacle monsters who fire lasers, and furry satans. Keep real life issues out of the video game... We have to deal with them enough outside of it.

The whole point of fantasy is to create an environment that is generally unrealistic. 

Of course this is a pretty pointless argument. Sex sells and as long as it does riot is gonna keep doing what they're doing. It's not like it's keeping you from playing the game. So it really can't be bothering you that much. 

You're probably gonna read my points and thrash me for them. I don't particularly care. You can argue that any champ is sexual if you try hard enough.

Another thing, if you don't mention your gender in chat people won't cling to you or treat you differently. Imagine that. There's this amazing thing on the internet called anonymity. If you don't want people to treat you differently, you don't have to tell them shit. You're the one putting yourself into that position. Everyone knows the community is full of teenage boys going through puberty. People also exploit this fact... (you being any individual not specifically op, because lets face it, I don't know your gender) 
Is it really that hard to keep your identity a secret from complete strangers....? 
I myself immediately assume all individuals are genderless until told otherwise.

tldr:
I'm tired of seeing social issues being brought to the game... goto reddit (I like reddit) they have places to disuss this.

I hope I discussed this properly. You know, because I assume you wanted to have a discussion and not to have someone lay back and agree with you.

>A lot of people come to escape that crap. 

If that were true people wouldn't immediately jump on board the "fuck women and feminism" train every time an art piece they didn't like got released. This has happened literally every time since Quinn even when it makes less sense than usual.

"Fiora is missing her bangs? FUCKING FEMINISM PISSING IN MY CHEERIOS!"

>Who cares if the characters in a video game don't represent real life... it's all fantasy. 

Because the two are not fundamentally separable. Where do you think all the ideas in this game come from?
No one is asking for total realism, but everything in this game and indeed all games on some level has referent within the real world, and by definition has to. It's not simply necessary in order for the creator to even make the content, its necessary in order for the player to understand the content.

Consequently it can't simply be ignored in total even if ones goal is not making a realistic game. It's even common for game designers to switch things within a game to match perceptions of a what a thing is rather than what it actually is, especially with mechanical objects.

This is also why Riot ends up changing things both in visuals and kit in order to make them "readable".

>This is a list of strong female characters who I wouldn't call overly sexualized

Annie is not sexualized? I certainly fucking hope she isn't.

The only champions there that aren't sexualized are Poppy and Annie.

>I'll admit, many characters are sexualized but sex does sell.

Very debatable. Typically sex in advertising only sells content when the content is specifically related to sex. Otherwise, it more often than not only serves to distract the audience away from whats being advertised.

>My list is from overly sexualized characters. The males fit the standards of what women find attractive in a male, and the women do it visa versa. 

This argument is fairly common, which is amusing because the same people who use it also tend argue that the games are played overwhelmingly by males and that things in games and made to appeal to males. It then follows that the "sexualized" male champions aren't made for female consumption at all and are at best designed around what men think women want, without regard for whether or not that is the case. Not that their views matter because, again, it's not made for them to begin with. It would then follow that these characters are made for the male audience but for what purpose? Couldn't possibly have to do with a power fantasy.

>I hope I discussed this properly. 

No, you don't. Your entire post after your commentaries on sexualized content largely serves to try and argue that this discussion is pointless and that it shouldn't be had and that your tired of it and that it doesn't matter. IE, you spend a good portion trying to neutralize the discussion you claim to want to discuss properly.

"Not sexist" lmao

A non serious fanservice skin that was created as a joke - while also opening up an actual lore possibility (as riven is pretty much jobless, exiled form her country and has not a single coin of gold, so she gotta work somewhere to get food). I would LOVE to read the story that led up to this scene - mostly BECAUSE it's so out-of-character for Riven to wear something like that.

I like this skin. So, does that make a now a bad person or whatever? because I appreciate a human individual looking good in a drawing? You got some weird moral compas here dude...
Ironic sexism is still sexism.

And a rose is a rose is a rose. Blah Blah.

It's a simple picture of a situation in the LoL-Universe.  Nothing more, nothing less. The sexism part is only added by thos interpretating the artwork. If you find the obviously neutral artwork offensive than that is your problem - maybe you should change the way you look at it then?
"Just stop seeing it as sexist, then it stops being sexist! =D"

Well, "sexism" is not anything you can measure by any kind of scientific method. It's a concept created in the minds of those who interpret something a certain way. Behavior can be sexist for example - a work of art showing a scene of any kind is not.

If you see everything as sexist, then the problem is with you, not with the world ^^
Yo why is this downvoted people? I can see Mona Liza as being sexist, anyone can, does that mean its sexist?

Because his post doesn't make any sense. Sexism as a concept is built entirely from real world interactions between groups of people and consequently has a set of criteria for experiential expectation. By definition, it can be measured.

Hell, if we accept that behavior can be sexist, then by definition we accept that sexism can also be measured.

Good luck trying to argue that behavior can't be measured, because that's required in order for his post to gain some semblance of cogency.

>Behavior can be sexist for example - a work of art showing a scene of any kind is not.

This is just plain stupid. Art creation is not separable from behavior and interpretation, either by the artist or by others, and consequently is not separable from the environmental conditioning which helped produce it.

First of all: the fact that there are SOME NOT HORRIBLE EXAMPLES doesn't mean there isn't an absurd majority of sexism in the design of female characters. This argument is usually thrown by sexism-enthusiasts. It is just as absurd as saying that 3 criminals in a house are innocent just because one of the roommates is innocent.

But lets play your game and go with the facts of your cherry-picked characters: 

Quinn: one of the few whose base design is not bad. Still, young and good looking in the standard euro-centric model of beauty. As every other female character. Winter skin incredibly sexist.

Kalista: lets compare it with Karthus or Thresh who are similar concepts/origin in male version. They are monsters. Skeleton faced. Completely horrid. Kalista meanwhile keeps a decent female face and mostly human parts, so important for an undead as breasts who will slightly show from the light clothes she wears. But hey, lets not suppose that it happened just because it is a female and has to look a bit pleasant to the eye. Right?

Annie: we could discuss here about all the anime-related stuff that Annie's concept comes from. A culture of over sexualizing girls in school uniform. but lets leave that out of the conversation because we are talking about a little girl and not an adult female and it would be completely horrid if she was also blatantly sexualized. 

Riven: a Champion that is supposed to be incredibly strong. Still she has sticks for arms. Just comparing it with her male counterparts, who are huge and muscled makes clear that female designs are not allowed to look like anything other than a standard western model. Her look makes no sense with the concept and that is because of the sexism behind the design. Because people don't want to fantasize about "super muscled women." Right?

Leona: exactly the same problem. Male tanks are HUGE. While a female tank still looks skinny and has the body of a standard model. Because female characters are not allowed to be anything else than that.

Poppy: not a human. Out of discussion.

Kayle: another young good looking female character but nothing much to actually complain about with her. I like her design inspired in Samus Aran. 

Sejuani: same problem as Leona. A tank looking just as skinny as Jinx. And of course the Traditional skin that has even less clothes than the normal one.

Holy crap you blew up on that guy, and made some horrible assumptions.

1. Poppy counts.  We're talking about gender here, not species.  Even if we were excluding non-human species Yordles are based off of human anatomy, so they would still count.
2. Annie counts.  Just because you don't like the idea of her being a problem area doesn't mean it won't be a problem if you don't discuss it.  Personally I don't think Riot created sexism problem here with Annie, but again no debate no answer.
3. "This argument is usually thrown by sexism-enthusiasts."  Holy fuck this is a worse assumption than anything I've seen from people disagreeing with you so far.  I'm actually tempted to report your post because of this blatant insulting of anyone who tries giving examples you do not think are good enough.

You are acting like a child here.  This is an adult topic, so please act like an adult and realize people will disagree with you, with some of them actually having valid points to bring up.  You can't just insult and ignore, or else you are part of the problem and should stop posting on adult topics.

I don't think he's thinking about how these issues impact the game.  Just talking about issues like that might not be appropriate for a gaming forum, but they are very applicable in the right context.

Long ago, around Diana release I think, there was a thread made that gave the very legit critique that Riot was making too many of the same body type champions. Riot got in on that thread and admitted that, yeah they were doing this and they didn't even notice. They even told us that they were going to actively try to expand the module types for all champions. I am certain had it not been for that and similar threads Bard, Rek'Sai, Zac, and others may not have been made.

But the threads created were not discussions on feminism or sexism or the like. They were about the game and ways to improve the overall experience of the game. Those threads would last page 1, if lucky, then the keyboard warriors would come in and derail the positive discussion and muddy the waters.

This is a Riot game forum for discussions on Riot games. Not a platform for political rhetoric.

How the hell do you get to a place where you literally think feminists are the reason sexist content doesn't change?

Also, the status quo is a thing.  By saying those people bringing up liberal politics are the problem, you side with the conservative politics already in place.

What on earth?  Unless he edited his post, which it doesn't look like he did, you drew a whole lot of conclusions out of nothing.

He made no comment on feminists, liberal politics, or even conservative politics.  In my experience this is why people like feminists and other very opinionated people get a bad rap online, because they have many similar minded people who put words into other people's mouths.

Please don't read between the lines when nothing is there, you'll just end up annoying people and making a fool of yourself.
Um, how do you not know what keyboard warriors refers to?

How do you think the term "keyboard warriors" refers to all feminists or those interested in talking about politics?  "Keyboard warriors" is a derogatory term, after all, and does not apply to opinionated people who know how to shut up when they are talking to someone who won't listen.  It's a term used to describe people who type and type to blindly defend something.

And yes, this also applies to conservatives, perhaps even more than liberals.  Things are not so black and white that the status quo is described by a single political side, after all, and I don't see liberals getting a near literal witch hunt on social media and network television.
